elements.content: Five new Cd­(II) complexes, {[Cd1.5(tzia)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (1), {[Cd1.5(tzia)­(H2O)4]·1.5H2O} n (2), [Cd­(H2tzia)2(H2O)4]·H2O (3), [Cd5(μ3-OH)­(tzia)3(H2O)7]·2H2O} n (4), and {[Cd2(μ3-OH)­(tzia)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (5) (H3tzia = 5-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­isophthalic acid), were assembled employing a tetrazolyl-carboxyl ligand H3tzia with Cd­(II) ions, revealing versatile structures from zero-dimensional (0D) mononuclear molecule, 2D layer to 3D framework, in which five new types of coordination modes of H3tzia were observed. Complex 1 shows a 3D (3,6)-connected ant net based on trinuclear [Cd3(COO)2(N4C)2] cluster; 2 forms an unusual 3D (3,4)-connected 3,4T1 net with 1D tubes based on the 26-membered metallocycles; 3 is a mononuclear molecule; 4 displays an unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected 2D layer based on pentanuclear [Cd5(μ3-OH)­(COO)2(N4C)3] cluster; 5 is a 3D porous framework containing 1D Cd-hydroxy-tetrazolyl ribbons. Complexes 1–5 exhibit strong luminescence with different energies resulted from the various coordination modes of tzia. The mechanism of luminescence was further investigated by density functional theory (DFT) calculations.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as solid-state materials, have been widely explored in luminescence, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage/separations, and magnetic and electronic applications, due to their fascinating structures and molecular topologies. In recent years, although much effort has focused on the design and controllable synthesis of MOFs with novel structures and special properties, the fabrication of desired MOFs is still challenging owing to many experimental factors, for instance, the type of metal ions, reaction solvents, and temperatures. The variety of metal ions, organic linkers, and structural motifs affords an essentially infinite number of possible combinations in which the structures of MOFs are controlled by the geometries of organic ligands. Among the plenty of ligands employed in the fabrication of MOFs, the multidentate N- and/or O-donor building blocks have received extensive attention. In this regard, the representative case is the isophthalatic acid substituted by azole group, which has been found to easily form clusters with metal ions, giving rise to a variety of porous MOFs (Scheme S1). Among the reported azolate-isophthalate ligands, the triazolate-isophthalate is most common. For example, in 5-(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)­isophthalatic acid, three triazolates connect one Cu3O core to form a triangular [Cu3O­(triazolate)3] trimer, and the carboxylates of isophthalate form [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel units; meanwhile, the 24 isophthalates and 12 [Cu2(COO)4] units produce a truncated cuboctahedra, which is linked by 24 trimers to yield a charming rht topological framework. The heterometal Co­(II)-Ln­(III)-MOFs with 5-(1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)­isophthalate possess the intriguing 3D networks, in which the N and O atoms owing to the hard–soft acid/base classification disclose preferential coordination with transition and lanthanide metal ions, respectively. Compared to triazolyl-isophthalate ligands, the tetrazolyl-substituted similarity, 5-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­isophthalic acid (H3tzia) with the separated tetrazolyl and isophthalic acid, contains more coordinated atoms, which would adopt more various coordination modes in the fabrication of MOFs. Moreover, H3tzia not only has the varied valences with the different degrees of deprotonation but also displays the different connection orientations relying on the dihedral angle between the azolate and phenyl ring, which was highly suitable to build the extended changeable and flexible frameworks (). However, H3tzia was used to construct MOFs in only a few reports in which the various coordination modes of H3tzia lead to the versatile frameworks with fantastic topologies. Thereby, the systemic investigations on the coordination properties of H3tzia would be appealing.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as solid-state materials, have been widely explored in luminescence, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage/separations, and magnetic and electronic applications, due to their fascinating structures and molecular topologies. In recent years, although much effort has focused on the design and controllable synthesis of MOFs with novel structures and special properties, the fabrication of desired MOFs is still challenging owing to many experimental factors, for instance, the type of metal ions, reaction solvents, and temperatures. The variety of metal ions, organic linkers, and structural motifs affords an essentially infinite number of possible combinations in which the structures of MOFs are controlled by the geometries of organic ligands. Among the plenty of ligands employed in the fabrication of MOFs, the multidentate N- and/or O-donor building blocks have received extensive attention. In this regard, the representative case is the isophthalatic acid substituted by azole group, which has been found to easily form clusters with metal ions, giving rise to a variety of porous MOFs (Scheme S1). Among the reported azolate-isophthalate ligands, the triazolate-isophthalate is most common. For example, in 5-(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)isophthalatic acid, three triazolates connect one Cu3O core to form a triangular [Cu3O(triazolate)3] trimer, and the carboxylates of isophthalate form [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel units; meanwhile, the 24 isophthalates and 12 [Cu2(COO)4] units produce a truncated cuboctahedra, which is linked by 24 trimers to yield a charming rht topological framework. The heterometal Co(II)-Ln(III)-MOFs with 5-(1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)isophthalate possess the intriguing 3D networks, in which the N and O atoms owing to the hard-soft acid/base classification disclose preferential coordination with transition and lanthanide metal ions, respectively. Compared to triazolyl-isophthalate ligands, the tetrazolyl-substituted similarity, 5-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)isophthalic acid (H3tzia) with the separated tetrazolyl and isophthalic acid, contains more coordinated atoms, which would adopt more various coordination modes in the fabrication of MOFs. Moreover, H3tzia not only has the varied valences with the different degrees of deprotonation but also displays the different connection orientations relying on the dihedral angle between the azolate and phenyl ring, which was highly suitable to build the extended changeable and flexible frameworks (). However, H3tzia was used to construct MOFs in only a few reports in which the various coordination modes of H3tzia lead to the versatile frameworks with fantastic topologies. Thereby, the systemic investigations on the coordination properties of H3tzia would be appealing.

Modes h–l are newly reported in complexes 1–5.

Considering all advantages mentioned above, we have successfully constructed a new series of five Cd­(II)-tzia complexes by adopting different Cd­(II) salt reactants, reaction temperatures, and solvents: {[Cd1.5(tzia)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (1), {[Cd1.5(tzia)­(H2O)4]·1.5H2O} n (2), [Cd­(H2tzia)2(H2O)4]·H2O (3), {[Cd5(μ3-OH)­(tzia)3(H2O)7]·2H2O} n (4), and {[Cd2(μ3-OH)­(tzia)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (5), wherein tzia shows five new coordination modes, leading to the multiple structures of 1–5. Complexes 1–5 display strong blue luminescence, and the luminescent mechanisms were investigated by density functional theory (DFT) calculations.

elements.content: All solvents and starting materials for synthesis were purchased commercially and were used as received. Infrared spectra (IR) were obtained in KBr discs on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined with a PerkinElmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a nitrogen stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All solvents and starting materials for synthesis were purchased commercially and were used as received. Infrared spectra (IR) were obtained in KBr discs on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined with a PerkinElmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a nitrogen stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å).

elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) and H3tzia (0.012 g, 0.05 mmol) in H2O (8 mL) was sealed in a vessel (25 mL). The vessel was heated at 170 °C for 72 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, giving the colorless block crystals of 1, which were isolated by washing with H2O, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 13.2 mg (58.2%, based on H3tzia). Anal. Calcd for C9H9Cd1.5N4O7: C, 23.82; H, 2.00; N, 27.78%. Found: C, 23.88; H, 2.09; N, 27.70%. elements.content: A Bruker Smart Apex II CCD detector was employed to obtain the crystal data of 1–5 at 296(2) K using ω rotation scans with widths of 0.3° and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 with the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms added at their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. Complex 5 contains the highly disordered solvent molecules that cannot be located from the difference Fourier map; therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used in structure refinement. Relevant crystallographic data and structure refinement results are listed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1. CCDC 1482060–1482064 (for 1–5) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this article.

Crystallography

A Bruker Smart Apex II CCD detector was employed to obtain the crystal data of 1-5 at 296(2) K using ω rotation scans with widths of 0.3° and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 with the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms added at their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. Complex 5 contains the highly disordered solvent molecules that cannot be located from the difference Fourier map; therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used in structure refinement. Relevant crystallographic data and structure refinement results are listed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1. CCDC 1482060-1482064 (for 1-5) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this article.

Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and consists of one and a half Cd atoms, one tzia, and two coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (). Both Cd1 and Cd2 are six-coordinated in which Cd1 is ligated by two carboxylate O atoms of two carboxylates, two tetrazolate 2-position N atoms, and two water O atoms, while Cd2 is surrounded by four carboxylate O atoms of three carboxylates, one tetrazolate 3-position N atom, and one water molecule. tzia in 1 is fully deprotonated and adopts a type-h mode that was previously not reported to link six Cd2+ centers (). One Cd1 and two Cd2 are bridged by two carboxylates and two tetrazolates of four tzia to form a trinuclear [Cd3(COO)2(N4C)2] cluster, with a 2-fold axis across central Cd1 atom. Notably, the trinuclear M3(azolate) m (COO) n SBUs with the different molar ratios of azolate and carboxylate have been observed in the past, yet the similar type of cluster with the same azolate and carboxylate components as shown in 1 is unobserved. One trinuclear cluster in 1 is connected with the adjacent two by four syn-anti carboxylate bridges of four tzia to form 1D chains along the c axis (a). The chain is extended by tzia to generate a 3D framework. The framework along the b axis has 21 helical chains with opposite chiralities, moreover, which form 1D channels filled by coordinated and lattice water molecules (a). Topologically, tzia and cluster in 1 can be regarded as 3- and 6-connected nodes, respectively; thus, the framework discloses a (3,6)-connected (426)2(44628810)-ant binodal net by Topos (b).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and contains one and a half Cd atoms, one tzia, and four water ligands in the asymmetric unit (a). Cd1 and Cd2 can be both described as six-coordinated in which Cd1 is coordinated by three O atoms of two different carboxylates, one tetrazolate 1-position N atom, and two water O atoms, while Cd2 is ligated by two tetrazolate 3-position N atoms and four water O atoms. tzia adopts a new type-i mode to bind four Cd2+ ions (). One Cd1 and one Cd2 are alternately linked by two tetrazolates and two tetrazolate-benzoate units to form a 26-membered metallocycle (b). The cycles are jointed together by benzolates of tzia to produce a 1D tube along the c axis, filled by water (O1W) ligands. The neighboring tubes are interlinked by the coordination of Cd2+ ions with carboxylate O atoms of tzia to afford a 3D framework, wherein a rectangular channel is encircled by four tubes along the c axis, which is occupied by coordinated and lattice water molecules (c). Topologically, Cd1 can be viewed as a 3-connected node. One tzia links three Cd1 and one Cd2 that serves as a 2-connected node between two tzia, so tzia can be simplified as a 4-connected node. As a result, the framework of 2 forms a bidonal (3,4)-connected 3,4T1 net with the pint symbol of (4·6·8)­(4·62·83) (d). Compared to those well-known (3,4)-connected nets, such as dmc, fry, pto, and moc nets, to the best of our knowledge, 3,4T1 net was reported in only four MOFs.

Crystal Structure of 2 

Complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and contains one and a half Cd atoms, one tzia, and four water ligands in the asymmetric unit (a). Cd1 and Cd2 can be both described as six-coordinated in which Cd1 is coordinated by three O atoms of two different carboxylates, one tetrazolate 1-position N atom, and two water O atoms, while Cd2 is ligated by two tetrazolate 3-position N atoms and four water O atoms. tzia adopts a new type-i mode to bind four Cd2+ ions (). One Cd1 and one Cd2 are alternately linked by two tetrazolates and two tetrazolate-benzoate units to form a 26-membered metallocycle (b). The cycles are jointed together by benzolates of tzia to produce a 1D tube along the c axis, filled by water (O1W) ligands. The neighboring tubes are interlinked by the coordination of Cd2+ ions with carboxylate O atoms of tzia to afford a 3D framework, wherein a rectangular channel is encircled by four tubes along the c axis, which is occupied by coordinated and lattice water molecules (c). Topologically, Cd1 can be viewed as a 3-connected node. One tzia links three Cd1 and one Cd2 that serves as a 2-connected node between two tzia, so tzia can be simplified as a 4-connected node. As a result, the framework of 2 forms a bidonal (3,4)-connected 3,4T1 net with the pint symbol of (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅62⋅83) (d). Compared to those well-known (3,4)-connected nets, such as dmc, fry, pto, and moc  nets, to the best of our knowledge, 3,4T1 net was reported in only four MOFs.

elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅, with one Cd atom, two H2tzia, and four coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (). Complex 3 is a mononuclear structure in which Cd1 has a distorted octahedral geometry defined by two tetrazolate N atoms and four water O atoms. In 3, H2tzia contains two uncoordinated −COOH groups and displays a new type-j mode (). In the crystal stack of 3, one molecule forms eight O–H···N hydrogen bonds (H···N = 1.831–1.965 Å, Table S2) involving four 1- and 2-position tetrazolate N atoms as H-acceptors and four uncoordinated −COOH groups as H-donors, producing an undulant 2D layer parallel to the ac crystallographic plane (a). Meanwhile, all coordinated H2O molecules as H-donors form interlayer O–H···O (H···O = 1.924–2.558 Å) hydrogen bonds with the carboxyl O atoms of H2tzia from neighboring layers, producing a 3D supramolecular framework (b).

Crystal Structure of 3 

Complex 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅, with one Cd atom, two H2tzia, and four coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (). Complex 3 is a mononuclear structure in which Cd1 has a distorted octahedral geometry defined by two tetrazolate N atoms and four water O atoms. In 3, H2tzia contains two uncoordinated -COOH groups and displays a new type-j mode (). In the crystal stack of 3, one molecule forms eight O-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds (H⋅⋅⋅N = 1.831-1.965 Å, Table S2) involving four 1- and 2-position tetrazolate N atoms as H-acceptors and four uncoordinated -COOH groups as H-donors, producing an undulant 2D layer parallel to the ac crystallographic plane (a). Meanwhile, all coordinated H2O molecules as H-donors form interlayer O-H⋅⋅⋅O (H⋅⋅⋅O = 1.924-2.558 Å) hydrogen bonds with the carboxyl O atoms of H2tzia from neighboring layers, producing a 3D supramolecular framework (b).

elements.content: Complex 4 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group P2 12121, with five Cd atoms, three tzia, one μ3-OH– group, and seven coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (). Cd1, Cd2, and Cd4 show distorted octahedral geometries: Cd1 is encircled by three tetrazolate N atoms of three tzia, one hydroxy O atom, and two water O atoms; Cd2 is coordinated by three tetrazolate N atoms of three tzia, one hydroxy O atom, and two chelating carboxylate O atoms of one tzia; Cd4 is ligated by one tetrazolate N atom and one carboxylate O atom of two tzia, one hydroxy O atom, and three water O atoms. Cd3 and Cd5 with seven-coordinated pentagonal bipyramid geometries possess the same O6N coordination environments defined by five carboxylate O atoms and one tetrazolate N atom of four tzia and one water O atom. tzia in 4 adopts type-k and -l coordination modes (). Cd1–Cd5 atoms are bridged by one μ3-OH–, one carboxylate with a μ4-η2,η2 fashion and three tetrazolates to form a pentanuclear [Cd5(μ3-OH)­(COO)2(N4C)3] cluster (a), which was previously not reported. One cluster in 4 is extended by ten tzia to generate a 2D layer parallel to the ab crystallographic plane (b,c). By regarding tzia with type-k and -l modes as 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively, and the cluster as 10-connected nodes, the layer of 4 reveals a trinodal (3,4,10)-connected topology with the point symbol of (43)2(45·6)­(421·624) (d). The trinodal high-connected nets are not well investigated in references because which require high-connected nodes, the 10-connected pentanuclear cluster in 4 is crucial to the formation of (3,4,10)-connected topology. The (3,4,10)-connected nets were only reported in sporadic MOFs, the same topology to 4 is unprecedented in the documented complexes.

Crystal Structure of 4 

Complex 4 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group P2 12121, with five Cd atoms, three tzia, one μ3-OH- group, and seven coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (). Cd1, Cd2, and Cd4 show distorted octahedral geometries: Cd1 is encircled by three tetrazolate N atoms of three tzia, one hydroxy O atom, and two water O atoms; Cd2 is coordinated by three tetrazolate N atoms of three tzia, one hydroxy O atom, and two chelating carboxylate O atoms of one tzia; Cd4 is ligated by one tetrazolate N atom and one carboxylate O atom of two tzia, one hydroxy O atom, and three water O atoms. Cd3 and Cd5 with seven-coordinated pentagonal bipyramid geometries possess the same O6N coordination environments defined by five carboxylate O atoms and one tetrazolate N atom of four tzia and one water O atom. tzia in 4 adopts type-k and -l coordination modes (). Cd1-Cd5 atoms are bridged by one μ3-OH-, one carboxylate with a μ4-η2,η2 fashion and three tetrazolates to form a pentanuclear [Cd5(μ3-OH)(COO)2(N4C)3] cluster (a), which was previously not reported. One cluster in 4 is extended by ten tzia to generate a 2D layer parallel to the ab crystallographic plane (b,c). By regarding tzia with type-k and -l modes as 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively, and the cluster as 10-connected nodes, the layer of 4 reveals a trinodal (3,4,10)-connected topology with the point symbol of (43)2(45⋅6)(421⋅624) (d). The trinodal high-connected nets are not well investigated in references because which require high-connected nodes, the 10-connected pentanuclear cluster in 4 is crucial to the formation of (3,4,10)-connected topology. The (3,4,10)-connected nets were only reported in sporadic MOFs, the same topology to 4 is unprecedented in the documented complexes.

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two Cd atoms, one tzia, one μ3-OH– group, and two coordinated water molecules (). Cd1 is trigonal-bipyramidally coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms, two tetrazolate 1-position N atoms of two tzia, and one hydroxy O atom. Cd2 displays a distorted octahedral geometry defined by two tetrazolate 2-position N atoms of two tzia, two hydroxy O atoms, and two water O atoms. tzia in 5 adopts a type-f coordination mode to link six Cd atoms () in which each carboxylate group bridges two Cd atoms, while the tetrazolate moiety through four N atoms connects four Cd atoms. The coordination mode of tzia in 5 is similar to a recently reported 3D Zn­(II)-MOF in which the phenyl and tetrazolyl rings with a dihedral angle of 81.9° is almost vertical. Three Cd atoms in 5 are bridged by one μ3-OH– and three tetrazolate groups to generate a triangular trinulear [Cd3(μ3-OH)­(N4C)3] cluster, surrounded by two carboxylates and four water ligands. In the cluster, one μ3-OH– connects three Cd atoms to form a isosceles triangle with the Cd···Cd separations of 3.863, 3.863, and 3.620 Å, respectively. The Cd3(μ3-OH) triangles are extended by corner-sharing to produce a 1D ribbon along the c axis, which is observed in only three metal–hydroxy-azolyl systems (a). Meanwhile, this ribbon also features an interesting zigzag Δ-chain arrangement for Cd2+ ions (b). The neighboring ribbons are interlinked by isophthalate units of tzia to give rise to a 3D framework, which contains 1D rectangular channels (sizes ca. 8.8 × 10.6 Å2) along the c axis, with the free voids of 32.4% (c). Notably, the activated sample of 5 at 115–130 °C under vacuum is almost nonadsorptive for N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K, which is possibly due to the structural distortion after the removal of water ligands (Figures S1 and S2).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 5 

Complex 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two Cd atoms, one tzia, one μ3-OH- group, and two coordinated water molecules (). Cd1 is trigonal-bipyramidally coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms, two tetrazolate 1-position N atoms of two tzia, and one hydroxy O atom. Cd2 displays a distorted octahedral geometry defined by two tetrazolate 2-position N atoms of two tzia, two hydroxy O atoms, and two water O atoms. tzia in 5 adopts a type-f coordination mode to link six Cd atoms () in which each carboxylate group bridges two Cd atoms, while the tetrazolate moiety through four N atoms connects four Cd atoms. The coordination mode of tzia in 5 is similar to a recently reported 3D Zn(II)-MOF in which the phenyl and tetrazolyl rings with a dihedral angle of 81.9° is almost vertical. Three Cd atoms in 5 are bridged by one μ3-OH- and three tetrazolate groups to generate a triangular trinulear [Cd3(μ3-OH)(N4C)3] cluster, surrounded by two carboxylates and four water ligands. In the cluster, one μ3-OH- connects three Cd atoms to form a isosceles triangle with the Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separations of 3.863, 3.863, and 3.620 Å, respectively. The Cd3(μ3-OH) triangles are extended by corner-sharing to produce a 1D ribbon along the c axis, which is observed in only three metal-hydroxy-azolyl systems (a). Meanwhile, this ribbon also features an interesting zigzag Δ-chain arrangement for Cd2+ ions (b). The neighboring ribbons are interlinked by isophthalate units of tzia to give rise to a 3D framework, which contains 1D rectangular channels (sizes ca. 8.8 × 10.6 Å2) along the c axis, with the free voids of 32.4% (c). Notably, the activated sample of 5 at 115-130 °C under vacuum is almost nonadsorptive for N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K, which is possibly due to the structural distortion after the removal of water ligands (Figures S1 and S2).

elements.content: The different structures of 1–5 indicate that the different anions, free and coordinated solvents, reaction temperatures, and solvents play vital roles in the formation of complexes (). It was interesting to find that the different anionic salts in the reactants cause the significant structure distinction of 1−3, which possibly results from the influence of different anions as templates though they do not exist in the respective structures; this phenomenon is rarely observed and differs from the situation that the distinct structures are formed by the coordination and/or fill of counteranions. Under the same condition except reaction temperatures, 3 and 4 are obtained; however, compared to the mononuclear molecule of 3 synthesized at 170 °C, 4 synthesized at 150 °C reveals a layer structure. The different structures should be attributed to the better solubility of H3tzia at a higher temperature, namely, H3tzia is more soluble during the preparation of 3, which leads to a higher mole ratio of tzia/Cd in 3 (2:1) relative to 4 (3:5). In addition, the decisive effect of solvent DMA employed in the synthesis of 5 is responsible for a porous framework due to the bulky DMA molecule, distinguishing from the other four complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Structures Diversity Induced by the Reaction Conditions and Coordination Modes of Ligand

The different structures of 1-5 indicate that the different anions, free and coordinated solvents, reaction temperatures, and solvents play vital roles in the formation of complexes (). It was interesting to find that the different anionic salts in the reactants cause the significant structure distinction of 1-3, which possibly results from the influence of different anions as templates though they do not exist in the respective structures; this phenomenon is rarely observed and differs from the situation that the distinct structures are formed by the coordination and/or fill of counteranions. Under the same condition except reaction temperatures, 3 and 4 are obtained; however, compared to the mononuclear molecule of 3 synthesized at 170 °C, 4 synthesized at 150 °C reveals a layer structure. The different structures should be attributed to the better solubility of H3tzia at a higher temperature, namely, H3tzia is more soluble during the preparation of 3, which leads to a higher mole ratio of tzia/Cd in 3 (2:1) relative to 4 (3:5). In addition, the decisive effect of solvent DMA employed in the synthesis of 5 is responsible for a porous framework due to the bulky DMA molecule, distinguishing from the other four complexes.

elements.content: In addition, the structural differences of 1–5, induced by different reaction conditions, are also significantly dependent on the various coordination modes of H3tzia. In 1, one tzia with a type-h mode links six Cd2+ ions through tetrazolate 2- and 3-position N atoms and two bidentate bridging carboxylates. In 2, one tzia with a type-i mode binds four Cd2+ ions through tetrazolate 1- and 3-position N atoms and one bidentate and one monodentate carboxylates. In contrast, H2tzia in 3 is a −1 valence ligand with a type-j mode that connects one Cd2+ ion through one tetrazolate N atom. In 4, two different tzia are observed, which adopt the type-k and -l modes to connect five and seven Cd2+ ions, respectively, forming an new (3,4,10)-connected framework. In 5, each tzia with a type-f mode links eight Cd2+ ions by four tetrazoltate N atoms and two bidentate bridging carboxylates. Moreover, another important difference in 5 is that the tetrazolate and central phenyl ring of tzia with a dihedral angle of 81.9° is almost vertical, whereas they are almost planar with the corresponding dihedral angles of 7.4° in 1, 14.8° in 2, 4.7° and 5.6° in 3, and 2.0, 46.6, and 59.2° in 4. This difference makes all four tetrazolate N atoms of one tzia in 5 coordinated to form a porous framework, differing from the situation of tzia in 1–4. Therefore, the changes of the reaction conditions and various coordination modes of H3tzia synergistically influence the structures of 1–5.

elements.content: The good matches between the experimental PXRD patterns of 1–5 and the simulated ones from single crystal structures confirm the phase purity (Figure S1). TGA of 1–5 were performed in a N2 atmosphere (Figure S2). Complex 1 shows two weight loss steps from 30 to 115 °C (6.4%) and 140 to 220 °C (4.7%), corresponding to the removal of two water ligands (calc. 7.9%) and one lattice water molecule (calc. 4.0%), respectively. The thermostable plateau is followed until ending at 345 °C, then the framework begins to decompose. Complex 2 releases all water molecules below 350 °C with a total weight loss of 19.3% (calc. 19.8%) and then is decomposed. Complex 3 loses the 14.6% weight before 270 °C, resulting from the release of five water molecules (calc. 13.5%), and then the framework decomposes. Complex 4 shows a slow 9.8% weight loss from 30 to 205 °C, indicating the departure of all water molecules (calc. 11.3%); subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework decomposes at 300 °C. For 5, the preliminary 8.6% weight loss from 30 to 130 °C is ascribed to the release of three water ligands (calc. 10.2%), and no further weight loss occurs before the structural collapse at 280 °C. TGA results verify the relatively higher decomposition temperatures of coordination polymers 1, 2, 4, and 5 than the 0D molecule 3. It can be attributed to the more coordinated N and O atoms and the more negative charges of H3tzia in 1, 2, 4, and 5, which form more robust frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Analysis

The good matches between the experimental PXRD patterns of 1-5 and the simulated ones from single crystal structures confirm the phase purity (Figure S1). TGA of 1-5 were performed in a N2 atmosphere (Figure S2). Complex 1 shows two weight loss steps from 30 to 115 °C (6.4%) and 140 to 220 °C (4.7%), corresponding to the removal of two water ligands (calc. 7.9%) and one lattice water molecule (calc. 4.0%), respectively. The thermostable plateau is followed until ending at 345 °C, then the framework begins to decompose. Complex 2 releases all water molecules below 350 °C with a total weight loss of 19.3% (calc. 19.8%) and then is decomposed. Complex 3 loses the 14.6% weight before 270 °C, resulting from the release of five water molecules (calc. 13.5%), and then the framework decomposes. Complex 4 shows a slow 9.8% weight loss from 30 to 205 °C, indicating the departure of all water molecules (calc. 11.3%); subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework decomposes at 300 °C. For 5, the preliminary 8.6% weight loss from 30 to 130 °C is ascribed to the release of three water ligands (calc. 10.2%), and no further weight loss occurs before the structural collapse at 280 °C. TGA results verify the relatively higher decomposition temperatures of coordination polymers 1, 2, 4, and 5 than the 0D molecule 3. It can be attributed to the more coordinated N and O atoms and the more negative charges of H3tzia in 1, 2, 4, and 5, which form more robust frameworks.

elements.content: The solid state UV–vis absorption spectra of 1–5 were measured at room temperature (Figure S4). The higher energy bands at 310, 296, 298, 302, and 276 nm for 1–5, respectively, are ascribed to the intraligand charge transitions. The semiconducting properties of 1–5 were investigated by diffuse reflectance spectra in Tauc plots (). The results indicate that 1–5 are wide-gap semiconductors with the band gaps of 3.66, 3.71, 3.68, 3.66, and 4.12 eV, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in other MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Semiconductor Behaviors of 1-5 

The solid state UV-vis absorption spectra of 1-5 were measured at room temperature (Figure S4). The higher energy bands at 310, 296, 298, 302, and 276 nm for 1-5, respectively, are ascribed to the intraligand charge transitions. The semiconducting properties of 1-5 were investigated by diffuse reflectance spectra in Tauc plots (). The results indicate that 1-5 are wide-gap semiconductors with the band gaps of 3.66, 3.71, 3.68, 3.66, and 4.12 eV, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in other MOFs.

elements.content: H3tzia in 1–5 can serve as a luminescent source due to the highly conjugated system. The solid state luminescent properties of free H3tzia and 1–5 were detected at room temperature ( and S5). H3tzia shows the luminescence with the strongest emission peak at 409 nm (λex = 363 nm), arising from the intraligand π* → π and/or π* → n charge transitions. The MO calculations of neutral H3tzia have been carried out for further verification. The contour plots of the relevant HOMO and LUMO with the orbital energies for H3tzia show that HOMOs are associated with the π-bonding orbital from the tetrazolyl and phenyl rings, while LUMOs are mainly associated with the π*-antibonding orbital from the phenyl ring (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

H3tzia in 1-5 can serve as a luminescent source due to the highly conjugated system. The solid state luminescent properties of free H3tzia and 1-5 were detected at room temperature ( and S5). H3tzia shows the luminescence with the strongest emission peak at 409 nm (λex = 363 nm), arising from the intraligand π* → π and/or π* → n charge transitions. The MO calculations of neutral H3tzia have been carried out for further verification. The contour plots of the relevant HOMO and LUMO with the orbital energies for H3tzia show that HOMOs are associated with the π-bonding orbital from the tetrazolyl and phenyl rings, while LUMOs are mainly associated with the π*-antibonding orbital from the phenyl ring (Figure S7).

elements.content: Complexes 1–5 exhibit bright blue luminescence under UV radiation. Compared to H3tzia, the emissions of 1–5 are red-shifted, and the maximum emissions are at 452 nm (λex = 344 nm), 442 nm (λex = 343 nm), 435 nm (λex = 361 nm), 443 nm (λex = 344 nm), and 434 nm (λex = 350 nm), respectively. For 1, 3, 4, and 5, both HOMOs are associated with the π-bonding orbital from tetrazolyl and phenyl rings (Figure S8), while LUMOs are mainly associated with π*-antibonding orbital from the tetrazolyl and phenyl rings. However, LUMOs for 2 are mainly associated with Cd–O and Cd–N σ*-antibonding orbitals, localized more on Cd atoms (Figure S8). Therefore, the luminescences of 1, 3, 4, and 5 can be assigned to πL* → πL ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT), while that of 2 can be designated to 5s → πL metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). In comparison to free H3tzia, the complexes are believed to strengthen the rigidity of frameworks and share the electrons in larger conjugated systems, and thus, the red-shift of emission occurs owing to the reduced energy loss during luminescent process. We further explore the mechanism of luminescence by DFT calculations. It indicates the obvious decreases of HOMO–LUMO gaps for 1–5 compared to H3tzia, which are consistent with the red-shifts of emission of 1–5 ().

elements.content: In summary, five Cd­(II)-tzia complexes with versatile structural features were constructed. Complex 1 shows a (3,6)-connected ant net based on [Cd3(COO)2(N4C)2] cluster. Complex 2 displays an unusual (3,4)-connected 3,4T1 net with 26-membered metallocycles. Complex 3 is a mononuclear molecule and forms a 3D supramolecular framework by intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Complex 4 contains a novel pentanuclear [Cd5(μ3-OH)­(COO)2(N4C)3] cluster, which is extended by tzia to form an unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected 2D layer. Complex 5 is a 3D porous framework containing 1D novel Cd-hydroxy-tetrazolyl ribbons based on [Cd3(μ3-OH)­(N4C)3] clusters. The changes of reaction conditions and various coordination modes of H3tzia corporately affect the structures of 1–5. Complexes 1–5 exhibit strong luminescence with different emission energies resulting from the various coordination modes of tzia. The DFT calculation verifies the luminescences of 1, 3, 4, and 5 arise from πL* → πL ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT); yet that of 2 is attributed to the ligation of ligand to metal center, 5s → πL metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). This presentation demonstrates that the varied coordination modes of H3tzia and other similar tetrazolyl-substituted multicarboxylic acid ligands could be the important building blocks in the fabrication of novel MOFs with colorful topologies and unique properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, five Cd(II)-tzia complexes with versatile structural features were constructed. Complex 1 shows a (3,6)-connected ant net based on [Cd3(COO)2(N4C)2] cluster. Complex 2 displays an unusual (3,4)-connected 3,4T1 net with 26-membered metallocycles. Complex 3 is a mononuclear molecule and forms a 3D supramolecular framework by intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Complex 4 contains a novel pentanuclear [Cd5(μ3-OH)(COO)2(N4C)3] cluster, which is extended by tzia to form an unprecedented (3,4,10)-connected 2D layer. Complex 5 is a 3D porous framework containing 1D novel Cd-hydroxy-tetrazolyl ribbons based on [Cd3(μ3-OH)(N4C)3] clusters. The changes of reaction conditions and various coordination modes of H3tzia corporately affect the structures of 1-5. Complexes 1-5 exhibit strong luminescence with different emission energies resulting from the various coordination modes of tzia. The DFT calculation verifies the luminescences of 1, 3, 4, and 5 arise from πL* → πL ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT); yet that of 2 is attributed to the ligation of ligand to metal center, 5s → πL metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). This presentation demonstrates that the varied coordination modes of H3tzia and other similar tetrazolyl-substituted multicarboxylic acid ligands could be the important building blocks in the fabrication of novel MOFs with colorful topologies and unique properties.

cln_elements.content:
The good matches between the experimental PXRD patterns of 1–5 and the simulated ones from single crystal structures confirm the phase purity (Figure S1). TGA of 1–5 were performed in a N2 atmosphere (Figure S2). Complex 1 shows two weight loss steps from 30 to 115 °C (6.4%) and 140 to 220 °C (4.7%), corresponding to the removal of two water ligands (calc. 7.9%) and one lattice water molecule (calc. 4.0%), respectively. The thermostable plateau is followed until ending at 345 °C, then the framework begins to decompose. Complex 2 releases all water molecules below 350 °C with a total weight loss of 19.3% (calc. 19.8%) and then is decomposed. Complex 3 loses the 14.6% weight before 270 °C, resulting from the release of five water molecules (calc. 13.5%), and then the framework decomposes. Complex 4 shows a slow 9.8% weight loss from 30 to 205 °C, indicating the departure of all water molecules (calc. 11.3%); subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework decomposes at 300 °C. For 5, the preliminary 8.6% weight loss from 30 to 130 °C is ascribed to the release of three water ligands (calc. 10.2%), and no further weight loss occurs before the structural collapse at 280 °C. TGA results verify the relatively higher decomposition temperatures of coordination polymers 1, 2, 4, and 5 than the 0D molecule 3. It can be attributed to the more coordinated N and O atoms and the more negative charges of H3tzia in 1, 2, 4, and 5, which form more robust frameworks.

Semiconductor Behaviors of <bold>1</bold>–<bold>5</bold>

The solid state UV–vis absorption spectra of 1–5 were measured at room temperature (Figure S4). The higher energy bands at 310, 296, 298, 302, and 276 nm for 1–5, respectively, are ascribed to the intraligand charge transitions. The semiconducting properties of 1–5 were investigated by diffuse reflectance spectra in Tauc plots (). The results indicate that 1–5 are wide-gap semiconductors with the band gaps of 3.66, 3.71, 3.68, 3.66, and 4.12 eV, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in other MOFs.

PXRD and Thermal Analysis

The good matches between the experimental PXRD patterns of 1-5 and the simulated ones from single crystal structures confirm the phase purity (Figure S1). TGA of 1-5 were performed in a N2 atmosphere (Figure S2). Complex 1 shows two weight loss steps from 30 to 115 °C (6.4%) and 140 to 220 °C (4.7%), corresponding to the removal of two water ligands (calc. 7.9%) and one lattice water molecule (calc. 4.0%), respectively. The thermostable plateau is followed until ending at 345 °C, then the framework begins to decompose. Complex 2 releases all water molecules below 350 °C with a total weight loss of 19.3% (calc. 19.8%) and then is decomposed. Complex 3 loses the 14.6% weight before 270 °C, resulting from the release of five water molecules (calc. 13.5%), and then the framework decomposes. Complex 4 shows a slow 9.8% weight loss from 30 to 205 °C, indicating the departure of all water molecules (calc. 11.3%); subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework decomposes at 300 °C. For 5, the preliminary 8.6% weight loss from 30 to 130 °C is ascribed to the release of three water ligands (calc. 10.2%), and no further weight loss occurs before the structural collapse at 280 °C. TGA results verify the relatively higher decomposition temperatures of coordination polymers 1, 2, 4, and 5 than the 0D molecule 3. It can be attributed to the more coordinated N and O atoms and the more negative charges of H3tzia in 1, 2, 4, and 5, which form more robust frameworks. 

Semiconductor Behaviors of 1-5 

The solid state UV-vis absorption spectra of 1-5 were measured at room temperature (Figure S4). The higher energy bands at 310, 296, 298, 302, and 276 nm for 1-5, respectively, are ascribed to the intraligand charge transitions. The semiconducting properties of 1-5 were investigated by diffuse reflectance spectra in Tauc plots (). The results indicate that 1-5 are wide-gap semiconductors with the band gaps of 3.66, 3.71, 3.68, 3.66, and 4.12 eV, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in other MOFs.
